facts.text: Panchanan Roy lodged a first information report at 11:00 p.m. on December 25, 1957, at the police station, Bhangor in the district of 24 Parganas alleging that respondent No. 1 Prokash Chandra Bose killed Nageswar Singh by shooting him with a gun.

facts.text: Nageswar Singh was a darwan posted at the informant's master's fishery.

facts.text: Pannalal Saha and Sankar Ghosh were arrested by the local people and produced in the police station.

anchor.surface_text: Two of his associates, Pannalal Saha and Sankar Ghosh, were arrested by the local people and produced in the police station.

facts.text: Police undertook investigation and submitted a final report on September 17, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the first information report, the police undertook investigation, but ultimately they submitted a final report as late as on September 17, 1958.

facts.text: Mahendra Singh filed a complaint on November 3, 1958 before Sub-Divisional Magistrate C. L. Choudhry against the police final report.

anchor.surface_text: against the final report of the police and asked for processes to be issued against certain other persons on the allegation that those persons had murdered Nageswar Singh. facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate C. L. Choudhry directed N. M. Chowdhry, Magistrate First Class, to hold a judicial enquiry into Mahendra Singh's allegations.

anchor.surface_text: After examining Mahendra Singh on oath and looking into the police papers, the learned Sub- Divisional Magistrate asked Mr. N. M. Chowdhry, Magistrate, First Class, to hold a judicial enquiry into the allegations made by Mahendra Singh

facts.text: Chandra Deo Singh, nephew of the deceased, filed a complaint on December 30, 1958 before Mr. Chowdhry alleging respondent No. 1 fired a shot at Nageswar Singh at point blank range.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the enquiry into the companyplaint of Mahendra Singh, Chandra Deo Singh, the nephew of the deceased filed a companyplaint before Mr. Chowdhry on December 30, 1958 stating therein that respondent No. 1 had fired a shot at Nageswar Singh at point blank range

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate referred Chandra Deo Singh's complaint to Mr. N. M. Chaudhry for enquiry and report.

anchor.surface_text: After examining him on oath, the Sub- Divisional Magistrate referred the matter again to Mr. N. M. Chaudhry Magistrate, First Class, for enquiry and report to him by a certain date.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 was permitted by the learned Magistrate to appear through counsel during the enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: During this enquiry, respondent No. 1 was permitted by the learned Magistrate to appear through companynsel.

facts.text: Seven witnesses were produced by complainant Chandra Deo Singh and examined by the learned Magistrate.

facts.text: On February 9, 1959, Mr. N. M. Choudhry reported prima facie case against Upendra Neogi, Asim Mondal and Arun Mondal under s. 302/34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On February 9, 1959, Mr. N. M. Choudhry made a report to the Sub-Divisional Magistrate to the effect that a prima facie case has been made out against three persons, Upendra Neogi, Asim Mondal and Arun Mondal under s. 302/34 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: On February 9, 1959, Mr. N. M. Choudhry reported no prima facie case against respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate directed summonses against Upendra Neogi, Asim Mondal and Arun Mondal and commenced committal proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the first report, the SubDivisional Magistrate directed summonses to be issued against the three persons named in that report and companymenced companymittal proceedings against them.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate dismissed Chandra Deo Singh's complaint without assigning any reason.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Divisional Magistrate on seeing the second report dismissed the companyplaint of Chandra Deo Singh without assigning any reason.

facts.text: Chandra Deo Singh preferred revision before Sessions Judge, Alipore, who directed further enquiry against respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: Chandra Deo Singh preferred an application for revision before the Sessions judge, Alipore, who, after issuing numberice to respondent No. 1 and hearing his companynsel, directed the Sub-Divisional Magistrate to make further enquiry against him.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 preferred revision application before Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon respondent No. 1 preferred a revision application before the High Court, which came up for hearing before a single judge of that companyrt.

facts.text: Upendra Neogi, Asim Mondal and Arun Mondal preferred revision before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear that the three persons against whom summonses were ordered to issue by the Sub-Divisional Magistrate also preferred a revision application before the High Court.

facts.text: High Court single judge granted revision applications of respondent No.1 and Upendra Neogy.

anchor.surface_text: Both the revision applications were heard together. The learned judge granted the application of respondent No.1 as well as that of Upendra Neogy.

facts.text: Appeal is Criminal Appeal No. 155 of 1960 by certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) from Calcutta High Court judgment dated January 27, 1960 in Criminal Revision No. 620 of 59.

arguments.claim: privilege under Ch. XVI CrPC to postpone process can be waived by accused who can then participate in enquiry

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, contended by Mr. Sethi for respondent No. 1 that the very object of the provisions of Ch. XVI of the Code of Criminal Procedure is to prevent an accused person from being harassed by a frivolous companyplaint and, therefore, power is given to a Magistrate before whom companyplaint is made to postpone the issue of summons to the accused person pending the result of an enquiry made either by himself or by a Magistrate subordinate to him. A privilege companyferred by these provisions can, according to Mr. Sethi, be waived by the accused person and he can take part in the proceedings.

arguments.claim: given prior police investigation and two conflicting Naraji complaints about one incident, proper to hold one full enquiry examining all evidence including defence witnesses, not one-sided

anchor.surface_text: The version of these two witnesses  Pannalal Saha and Sankar Ghose  is supported by the fact that the police when they went to the locality found a dead bird and a pair of shoes and a pair of black half pants in wet companydition. This find of the dead bird and the pair of shoes etc. has number explained on the version given by Panchanan Roy, Upendra Mondal and Tarapado Naru. Mr. Ajit Kumar Dutt stated that the inquiring Magistrate was number right in examining Pannalal Saha and Shankar Ghose at the suggestion of an advocate for the accused Chabbi Bose and that the latter should number have been allowed at the inquiry. When however there had already been a full investigation into the case by the officers under the supervision of the Superintendent of Police, it was desirable and proper for the inquiring magistrate to make a careful inquiry and number merely an one sided inquiry by examining such witnesses as might be produced by an interested party. Moreover, in this case, the learned magistrate was inquiring into both the companyplaints simultaneously and necessarily be companyld look at the evidence as a whole.

arguments.claim: under scheme of Ch. XVI CrPC, accused has no right to participate in s.202 enquiry until process issued; Magistrate has no jurisdiction to permit it

anchor.surface_text: Taking the first ground, it seems to us clear from the entire scheme of Ch. XVI of the Code of Criminal Procedure that an accused person does number companye into the picture at all till process is issued. This does number mean that he is precluded from being present when an enquiry is held by a Magistrate. He may remain present either in person or through a companynsel or agent with a view to be informed of what is going on But since the very question for companysideration being whether he should be called upon to face an accusation, he has numberright to take part in the proceedings number has the Magistrate any jurisdiction to permit him to do so.

arguments.claim: s.202 enquiry is to ascertain if sufficient ground for proceeding based on complainant's evidence only, not to weigh for conviction or conduct trial

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the second ground, we have numberhesitation in holding that the test propounded by the learned single judge of the High Court is wholly wrong. For determining the question whether any process is to be issued or number, what the Magistrate has to be satisfied is whether there is sufficient ground for proceeding and number whether there is sufficient ground for the companyviction.

arguments.claim: s.203 requires Magistrate to record brief reasons for dismissal; failure vitiates if prejudice caused, not curable under s.537

anchor.surface_text: Section 203 of the Code of Criminal Procedure which empowers a, Magistrate to dismiss a companyplaint reads thus The Magistrate before whom a companyplaint is made or to whom it has been transferred, may dismiss the companyplaint, if, after companysidering the statement on oath  if any  of the companyplainant and the witnesses and, the result of the investigation or inquiry, if any, under s. 202, there is in his judgment numbersufficient ground for proceeding. In such case he shall briefly record his reasons for so doing.

holdings.text: An accused person does not come into the picture at all till process is issued and has no right to take part in the proceedings under s.202 CrPC nor has the Magistrate any jurisdiction to permit him to do so; the enquiry is vitiated if participation is allowed.

anchor.surface_text: Taking the first ground, it seems to us clear from the entire scheme of Ch. XVI of the Code of Criminal Procedure that an accused person does not come into the picture at all till process is issued. This does not mean that he is precluded from being present when an enquiry is held by a Magistrate. He may remain present either in person or through a counsel or agent with a view to be informed of what is going on But since the very question for consideration being whether he should be called upon to face an accusation, he has no right to take part in the proceedings nor has the Magistrate any jurisdiction to permit him to do so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Ch. XVI CrPC excludes accused until process issued; permitting participation allows defence evidence, frustrating object of enquiry to test complaint's truth from complainant's side only.

holdings.text: This inference is irresistible and we hold that on this ground, the enquiry made by the enquiring Magistrate is vitiated.

anchor.surface_text: This inference is irresistible and we hold that on this ground, the enquiry made by the enquiring Magistrate is vitiated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court witnesses Pannalal Saha and Sankar Ghosh examined at instance of respondent's counsel; they were alleged associates, inference of participation irresistible.

holdings.text: The test propounded by the learned single judge of the High Court for determining whether process should be issued is wholly wrong; Magistrate must determine if there is sufficient ground for proceeding, not for conviction.

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the second ground, we have no hesitation in holding that the test propounded by the learned single judge of the High Court is wholly wrong. For determining the question whether any process is to be issued or not, what the Magistrate has to be satisfied is whether there is sufficient ground for proceeding and not whether there is sufficient ground for the conviction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scope of s.202 enquiry is to ascertain truth/falsehood of complaint from complainant's evidence; conviction adequacy determined at trial only; precedents confirm.

holdings.text: A Magistrate making enquiry under s.202 CrPC has no jurisdiction to weigh evidence in golden scales as in a trial; what Magistrate could not do, High Court incompetent to do.

anchor.surface_text: What the Magistrate could not do, the High Court was incompetent to do, and, therefore, its order reversing that of the Sessions judge cannot be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry limited to complainant's evidence; High Court weighed defence evidence, police investigation extraneous to s.202/203; separate complaints not to be merged.

holdings.text: Under s.203 CrPC, Magistrate dismissing complaint must briefly record reasons; failure goes to root, causes prejudice to complainant in revision, vitiates order.

anchor.surface_text: Section 203 of the Code of Criminal Procedure which empowers a, Magistrate to dismiss a complaint reads thus The Magistrate before whom a complaint is made or to whom it has been transferred, may dismiss the complaint, if, after considering the statement on oath  if any  of the complainant and the witnesses and, the result of the investigation or inquiry, if any, under s. 202, there is in his judgment no sufficient ground for proceeding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.203 mandates reasons; Sub-Divisional Magistrate dismissed without; prejudice in revision under ss.438/439 as complainant ignorant of grounds.

holdings.text: Failure to record reasons under s.203 CrPC is not mere curable irregularity under s.537 CrPC where prejudice caused.

anchor.surface_text: It is stated on behalf of respondent No. 1 that this is at best an error in his order and, therefore, it is curable under s. 537   of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Error jurisdictional, prerequisite for valid dismissal; prejudice writ large, unlike Slaney case; affects revision rights.

holdings.text: The High Court was in error in setting aside the order of the Sessions Court and further enquiry must be made into the complaint against respondent No.1.

anchor.surface_text: For all these reasons, we hold that the High Court was in error in setting aside the order of the Sessions Court and direct that further enquiry be made into the complaint of the appellant against respondent No. 1.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative errors in enquiry, test, weighing, reasons vitiate; independent of proceedings against other accused.

holdings.text: Vadilal does not lay down inflexible rule prohibiting Magistrate from considering plea of private defence at s.202 stage if applied judicially without misdirection.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance is however, placed by Mr. Sethi on the decision of this Court in Vadilals case  1 , at p. 10 of the report. What was considered there by this Court was whether as a matter of law, it was not open to a Magistrate to accept the plea of the right of private defence at a state when all that he had to determine was whether process is to issue or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Vadilal permits consideration if self-defence falsifies complaint evidence judicially; no inflexible bar; but no such plea or contradiction here.

anchor.surface_text: Taking the first ground, it seems to us clear from the entire scheme of Ch. XVI of the Code of Criminal Procedure that an accused person does not come into the picture at all till process is issued. This does not mean that he is precluded from being present when an enquiry is held by a Magistrate. He may remain present either in person or through a counsel or agent with a view to be informed of what is going on But since the very question for consideration being whether he should be called upon to face an accusation, he has no right to take part in the proceedings nor has the Magistrate any jurisdiction to permit him to do so.
For all these reasons, we hold that the High Court was in error in setting aside the order of the Sessions Court and direct that further enquiry be made into the companyplaint of the

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the second ground, we have no hesitation in holding that the test propounded by the learned single judge of the High Court is wholly wrong. For determining the question whether any process is to be issued or not, what the Magistrate has to be satisfied is whether there is sufficient ground for proceeding and not whether there is sufficient ground for the conviction.
For all these reasons, we hold that the High Court was in error in setting aside the order of the Sessions Court and direct that further enquiry be made into the companyplaint of the

anchor.surface_text: Section 203 of the Code of Criminal Procedure which empowers a, Magistrate to dismiss a complaint reads thus The Magistrate before whom a complaint is made or to whom it has been transferred, may dismiss the complaint, if, after considering the statement on oath  if any  of the complainant and the witnesses and, the result of the investigation or inquiry, if any, under s. 202, there is in his judgment no sufficient ground for proceeding.
For all these reasons, we hold that the High Court was in error in setting aside the order of the Sessions Court and direct that further enquiry be made into the companyplaint of the
